Award.AwardTitle: Limits of Information Flow in Networks of Two-Way Channels

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Communication networks are critically important in the<br/>dissemination of information in today's technological<br/>society. Several academic disciplines have undertaken<br/>the study of various aspects of their operation, but<br/>an integrated theory of networking has been elusive.<br/>The objective of network optimization theory is to<br/>most effectively use network resources, but recent<br/>work in network coding has demonstrated that a standard<br/>assumption of flow conservation from this theory has<br/>imposed artificial restrictions on the workings of<br/>communication networks. Network information theory<br/>considers more general models of communication and<br/>offers some bound on the limits of information transfer<br/>in a communication system involving multiple senders<br/>and receivers.<br/><br/>This research fuses aspects of network optimization<br/>theory and network information theory in order to find<br/>and specify new limits of information transfer across<br/>a communication network. The investigators use the<br/>two-way channel from information theory as a general<br/>model of the transmission medium between neighboring<br/>processors of a communication network and address<br/>fundamental optimization problems pertaining to the<br/>analysis and design of networks of two-way channels.<br/>The investigators seek optimal routing algorithms in<br/>multicast settings and a broad classification of<br/>situations where network coding can or cannot improve<br/>upon routing. The investigators further aim to<br/>categorize network scenarios in which a bidirected<br/>cut set bound derived using information theoretic<br/>arguments is tight and to explore a network information<br/>counterpart to Kirchoff's law when the bidirected<br/>cut set bound is not tight. The research also<br/>involves extending the notion of minimal cost flow<br/>as an initial approach to treating quality-of-service<br/>issues and devising networks with least cost or<br/>capacity that meet requirements on information transfer.<br/>
